questions.question: What techniques were used to analyze the series of medium- and long-chain zinc carboxylates?
questions.answer: Ultra-high-field 67Zn NMR spectroscopy up to 35.2 T, 13C NMR, FTIR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

questions.question: What distinct geometric groups were the carboxylates classified into based on structural and spectroscopic parameters?
questions.answer: The carboxylates exist in three distinct geometric groups.

questions.question: Why were zinc nonanoate, zinc decanoate, and zinc oleate specifically mentioned in the context of single-crystal X-ray diffraction structures?
questions.answer: They were the first long-chain carboxylate single-crystals to be reported for zinc, providing valuable structural information.

questions.question: Zinc oxide has been used as a pigment since antiquity.
The formation of zinc carboxylates in oil paintings is a non-concern for cultural heritage conservators.
How does the presence of a cis-double bond in zinc oleate affect its classification among the geometric groups?
questions.answer: The cis-double bond prevents the all-trans arrangement of aliphatic chains, affecting structural alignment and classifying it in a specific geometric group despite its longer chain.

questions.question: All zinc carboxylates exhibit similar 67Zn NMR spectroscopic parameters.
What is the significance of the quadrupole coupling constant (CQ) in the context of 67Zn NMR spectroscopy for analyzing zinc carboxylates?
questions.answer: The CQ is highly sensitive to the local environment around the zinc center, providing insights into the structural arrangement and electronic environment.

questions.question: Why is zinc pivalate placed in a separate group based on its 67Zn NMR spectroscopic parameters?
questions.answer: Zinc pivalate has a large quadrupole coupling constant due to the distorted tetrahedral arrangement around zinc centers, caused by sterically bulky ligands, distinguishing it from other carboxylates.
